column4: I have a problem with an ssh server daemon. I think it is a router/network issue is there some one that can point me in the right direction to find out how to deal with it?
describe the signs and symptoms please
well, i have turned off UseDNS in ssh, but when i try and ssh into my ubuntu machine from my mac ( from my own network ) i have to wait about a minute and a half before i get a password prompt.
you should add an /etc/hosts entry on ubuntu for your mac.
pretty certain it will work. Agree about the router.
kairu0: hasn't seemed to make any difference
Just booting my own mac to try

I think it might have to do with my router combined with ubuntu, it's a dlink, i can ssh into the mac instantly. but trying to get into the ubuntu box, just takes a long time :( and unfortunatly it's my main box
strange, I get no delay at all even without a hosts entry. Consider running ssh with debugging info.
ssh -v
oh i didn't even know there was one, i will look it up, ah thanks I don't even have to look it up, you are the man
i have the error. :D which means i'm alot closer to solving it

sorry just getting used to the ubuntu way of copying between consoles :) it was: An invalid realm for numeric host was supplied /n malform parm [sic]  /n cannot determine relm for numeric host address /n validation errer
? is the name i stick in the hosts file, next to the ip important? or can it be anything, i.e. does it have to be exactly the same as the comp name/ network name of the mac?
it doesn't matter
just what i thougt. any idea what the 'Cannot determine realm for numeric host address' would relate to ?
no. Try throwing it at a web search engine?
would the shh channel throw me out for asking such a noob question if i went in and asked it ? :)
don't know, never been there. Read the topic, spend some time lurking, and then see if you want to take the risk ;)
thanks for all of you help. Please accept my thanks :D
glad I could assist
it's probably poorly supported by your hardware.
is there a away to narrow down which bit it is?
you could reverse-compile your DSDT with iasl and check for compile errors.
